_header: Behold mine wounds how sore I am dight
Subjects: Christ, attributes of; Christ, appeal of, to man; crucifixion
_description: Christ as Man’s Champion, a tag in the Fasciculus morum (except Cambridge UK, Corpus Christi College 392) — four lines, in three different versions, the first couplet freely translating a distich from Ovid’s Amores

Bod410.Transcription:
Be holde my woundes how i am dyghtfor all þi wele I won In
                    fyghtI am sore wounded byholde my skyn& for my loue þu let me
                    In

BodLauMis213.Transcription:
By hold my woundes how I am dightffor all þi wole I won &
                    fightI am fore woundyd by hold my skynand for my loue þu lete me
                    in
BodLauMis213.Editions:
Gray,  Douglas,
                        ed.  
             A Selection of Religious Lyrics.
Clarendon Medieval and Tudor Series.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1975: 124.

BodRawC670.Transcription:
Beholde myne woundes how sore I am dyȝthFfor all þe wele
                    þat þou hast I wan hit in fyȝtI am sore woundet behold on my
                    skynLeue lyf for my loue let me comen in
BodRawC670.Editions:
Woolf,  Rosemary. 
             “The Theme of Christ the Lover-Knight in Medieval English
                Literature.” 
             Review of English Studies
         n.s. 13 (1962): 1-16: 7.
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 160.

Be hold my woundes wide man and seMy bood þat i schedde in
                    batayl for the

OxfLinLat52.Transcription:
By hold my wondes wyde man and seeMy blode þat I schadd in
                    batell for the

CamCCC392.Transcription:
By hold my wondys how sore y am dyȝtfor al þy welthe
                    þat þu hast y wan hyt yn fyȝty am sore wondyt be hold on my
                    skynleue lef for my loue lat me com yn
CamCCC392.Note:
Not in Fasciculus morum but rather in a sermon on Christ’s
                    Passion, headed, ‘Maria Ihesu Johannes Dunstanus assint principio
                        meo’ (f. 253).

CamGon71.Transcription:
By hald my woundeȝ how sore I am dygthffor all þe wele
                    þat þu has I wanne wyth rygthI am sore wounded be hald my
                    scynleue lef for my loue lat me com In

CamStJohn159.Transcription:
By hold my wondys sore I ame diȝtffor all þi wyl þat
                    þu hast yawn it in fiȝtI am sor wondyt be halde on my
                    skynlef lyfe for my lofe lat me Ine

DULCosViv2.Transcription:
By hold my wondys how sore þat I am dyhtffor all þi wele
                    þat þu hasse I wan it in fyghtI am sore wonded by hald in my
                    skynLeue lyf for my lofe latt me come In

EDU82.Transcription:
By holde my wowndes how sore I am dygthffor all the wele that thou
                    hast I wan the in fygthI am sore wownded by holde on my skynleve lefe
                    for my lofe lat me com in

Lincoln44.Transcription:
Byholde my wondys hov sore y am dyȝtffor al þy welþe
                    þat þu hast y wan hyt on syȝty sore wondyd by hold on my
                    skynleue lofe for my luf let me come yn

Spalding.Transcription:
Beholde my wondes how sorye I am dyghtffor all þe welth þat
                    þu has I wan hit in fyghtI am sore woundyde beholde now my
                    skynleue lofe lat me come in

WorcF19.Transcription:
by holdit my wondis how sore y an dyghtffor alle þy welle
                    þat þu hast q wonne hit with ryȝt

WorcQ3.Transcription:
be holde my wondes wyde how sore I am dyȝtAl þe wele
                    þow hast I wan hit in syȝtI am wounndyt sore by hold on my
                    scynGentyll lefe fors my loue let me com In

VaticanOtto.First Lines:
Behold my woundys in thys caasHow sor I am
                    dyhte…
VaticanOtto.Last Lines: …Der leman for my lofLate me cum Ine
VaticanOtto.Editions:
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 161.
